Award.AwardTitle: CGV: Small: Towards Computational Stereoscopic Cinematography

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Stereoscopic 3D provides an immersive viewing experience and has evoked a tremendous amount of interest. However, stereoscopic content must be properly produced to avoid "3D fatigue," such as blurring vision, eyestrain, and headache. The difficulty in producing stereoscopic content has become a bottleneck that limits its impact.

This research develops computational stereoscopic cinematography technologies to assist stereoscopic content production by integrating computer graphics, computer vision, stereoscopic cinematography, and stereo perception. This project explores fundamental and unique problems in computational stereoscopic cinematography: how to edit disparity to deliver a pleasant viewing experience; how disparity interacts with other aspects of stereoscopic content like monocular depth cues and motion; how to optimize disparity during stereoscopic content manipulation and authoring, including warping, collage authoring, and video stabilization; how to coordinate the process of the left and right view with no or unreliable stereo correspondences; and how to extend monocular content manipulation and authoring technologies to stereoscopic content in a principled way. In short, this project solves key problems in computational stereoscopic cinematography and establishes general principles for developing stereoscopic content processing and authoring technologies.

This computational stereoscopic cinematography research facilitates high-quality stereoscopic content production, which is critical in sustaining and boosting the impact of stereoscopic 3D in a variety of applications, including virtual reality, human computer interaction, scientific visualization, educational training, and medical rehabilitation. The research results, including the technical writings, the stereoscopic image/video library, and the code infrastructure, are disseminated through paper publications and online sharing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated computational stereoscopic cinematography technologies. Stereoscopic 3D provides an important way to deliver immersive 3D viewing experience and enables applications in areas, ranging from entertainment and education to health care. It is also valuable for increasingly popular virtual reality applications. However, stereoscopic content must be very carefully produced; otherwise it will cause 3D fatigue, which has been a long-standing obstacle of sustaining and boosting the impact of stereoscopic 3D.

This project studied the current practice and challenges in stereoscopic cinematography, and investigated paradigms of developing computational tools to assist stereoscopic content production. By integrating stereo perception, cinematography, and methodologies of computer graphics, computer vision, human computer interaction, and machine learning, the PI and his team identified key stereoscopic content production problems and invented corresponding computational stereoscopic cinematography technologies, such as stereo video stabilization, stereo stitching, depth enhancement, and novel view interpolation. The research was also extended from conventional (binocular) stereoscopic content to multi-view auto stereoscopic video and stereoscopic VR video and brought in novel authoring and reviewing interfaces and tools for these emerging visual media.

The project results are disseminated through publications in premiere venues and online source code and data sharing. The research from this project has been integrated into the PI’s visual computing curriculum and trained PhD students, most of whom continue their research career after graduation in leading research labs in the fields. This project also provided research opportunities for high school students and students from underrepresented groups.
